posts.post_content:
[Zealous Inquisitor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Zealous Inquisitor), Boros edition.  
  
The first strike option doesn't quite synergize with his triggered ability.  
But it's an advantage nonetheless - especially if you're facing other first strikers, or want him to survive a combat.  
  
Overall a really efficient creature, and also one your opponent definitely doesn't want to try their burn spells on.

posts.post_content:
Everyone sees a great card. It is.  
  
Some people see an almost strictly better [Spitemare](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Spitemare) (the mare is more splashable)... I see a mana curve.  
  
Turn 2, [Mogg Maniac](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mogg Maniac). Turn 3, this. Turn 4, Spitemare. Turn 5, [Stuffy Doll](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Stuffy Doll).  
  
This is the casual deck of doom. Throw in a few fun cards like [Blood Lust](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Blood Lust) or [Blood Frenzy](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Blood Frenzy) (to play on your opponent's creatures, if they attack / block, or on yours if they aren't blocked - or even to screw up two opponents in multi-player), the always useful [Brute Force](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Brute Force), board sweepers like [Earthquake](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Earthquake) (or [Starstorm](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Starstorm) if you need help with fliers), the already mentioned [Blasphemous Act](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Blasphemous Act) as win-more...  
  
And the killer combo that was born back when the Mogg was the only creature we had that did this: add a couple of [Furnace of Rath](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Furnace of Rath) and [Reckless Abandon/autocar](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Reckless Abandon/autocar)... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
Everyone sees a great card. It is.

Some people see an almost strictly better Spitemare (the mare is more splashable)... I see a mana curve.

Turn 2, Mogg Maniac. Turn 3, this. Turn 4, Spitemare. Turn 5, Stuffy Doll.

This is the casual deck of doom. Throw in a few fun cards like Blood Lust or Blood Frenzy (to play on your opponent's creatures, if they attack / block, or on yours if they aren't blocked - or even to screw up two opponents in multi-player), the always useful Brute Force, board sweepers like Earthquake (or Starstorm if you need help with fliers), the already mentioned Blasphemous Act as win-more...

And the killer combo that was born back when the Mogg was the only creature we had that did this: add a couple of Furnace of Rath and Reckless Abandon/autocar... (see all)

Great card tho, I always liked Spitemare, I just don't play red/white so these made awesome trade fodder...

posts.post_content:
Far too powerful. The [Thragtusk](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Thragtusk) of Gatecrash sadly. Not quite as bad though.  
  
I feel it should have been target player only.  
  
Ironically, it answers Thragtusk very well. It can first strike kill either Thragtusk or the Beast token and even if you don't have the mana to first strike it, it'll still kill the Thragtusk and be able to deal 5 damage to something else (but not the beast token, since that enters after Reckoner's ability resolves).

posts.post_content:
@Kr-azi  
  
Because of the state-based action outlined in 704.5g:  
"If a creature has toughness greater than 0, and the total damage marked on it is greater than or equal to its toughness, that creature has been dealt lethal damage and is destroyed."  
  
Say Reckoner is dealt 1 point of damage by something...  
- Reckoner's 'dealt damage' trigger goes on the stack (choosing to deal damage to itself); it resolves, assuming no one does anything, dealing one damage to the Reckoner  
- a second instance of Reckoner's dealt damage trigger goes on the stack (choosing to deal damage to itself); it resolves, assuming no one does anything, dealing one damage to the Reckoner (Reckoner now has 2 damage marked on it)  
- a third instance of Reckoner's 'dealt damage' trigger goes on the stack (choosing to deal damage to itself); it resolves, assuming no one does anything, dealing one damage to the Reckoner (Reckoner now has 3 damage marked on it and will be destroyed because of the state-based action outlined a... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
@Kr-azi

Because of the state-based action outlined in 704.5g:
"If a creature has toughness greater than 0, and the total damage marked on it is greater than or equal to its toughness, that creature has been dealt lethal damage and is destroyed."

Say Reckoner is dealt 1 point of damage by something...
- Reckoner's 'dealt damage' trigger goes on the stack (choosing to deal damage to itself); it resolves, assuming no one does anything, dealing one damage to the Reckoner
- a second instance of Reckoner's dealt damage trigger goes on the stack (choosing to deal damage to itself); it resolves, assuming no one does anything, dealing one damage to the Reckoner (Reckoner now has 2 damage marked on it)
- a third instance of Reckoner's 'dealt damage' trigger goes on the stack (choosing to deal damage to itself); it resolves, assuming no one does anything, dealing one damage to the Reckoner (Reckoner now has 3 damage marked on it and will be destroyed because of the state-based action outlined a... posts.post_content:
Why does everyone keep including the Boros Charm for indestructibility in the infinite life combo? He doesn't have to survive, does he? The rulings on the first page specifically say that he will still deal damage even if he receives lethal damage. Doesn't this mean that you can just get lifelink on him, Searing Spear him once, and win?   
  
What am I missing? Why the indestructibility?

Posted By: Kr-azi (3/12/2013 11:53:21 PM)

posts.post_content:
he's a great card, but there are some answers for him.   
  
I personally have no problem dropping a searing spear into him if a player drops him on turn 3. They're unlikely to have the mana to kick off the infinite life combo, and he represents such a huge threat, that if you end up taking 3 to the face, it's probably worth it. With the deck I play, I've found it very profitable to just go ahead and trade a Loxodon Smiter for him. If they want to send 3 to my face, sure, their reckoner still dies, and I keep my 4/4. Or we can just trade straight up. Or he can take out my Thragtusk and I still get a 3/3.   
  
Flyers can just ignore him. Sure, if I have stuff I care about on the board, I'm not going to block him and risk him taking something else out, but if I'm running flyers, I'm more than happy to take 3 each round and swing back with a bigger flyer.   
  
Trample effects make his damage redirection not such a big deal, limiting him to 3 in most cases. With the popularity of Wolf Run, I'm perfe... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

Or we can just trade straight up. Or he can take out my Thragtusk and I still get a 3/3.

Flyers can just ignore him. Sure, if I have stuff I care about on the board, I'm not going to block him and risk him taking something else out, but if I'm running flyers, I'm more than happy to take 3 each round and swing back with a bigger flyer.
